title: Introduction to Loops and Loop Control

questions.question: What is a loop?

options.value: A control structure that repeatedly executes a block of code

questions.explanation: A loop is a control structure that repeatedly executes a block of code as long as a specified condition remains true, automating repetitive tasks.

questions.question: What are the three types of loops in Java?
questions.explanation: Java provides three types of loops: while loops, do-while loops, and for loops, each serving specific purposes in controlling repetition.

questions.question: What are the three essential components of every loop?
questions.explanation: Every loop has three essential components: initialization (sets up variables), condition (determines if loop continues), and update (modifies variables toward termination).

questions.question: What is an iteration?

options.value: A single execution of the loop body

questions.explanation: An iteration is a single execution of the loop body. Each time the loop repeats its code block, that counts as one iteration.

questions.question: What are loop variables?

options.value: Variables that control loop execution and typically change with each iteration

questions.explanation: Loop variables control loop execution and typically change with each iteration, allowing the loop to make progress toward termination.
This loop iterates 3 times with i values of 0, 1, and 2. When i reaches 3, the condition i < 3 becomes false and the loop stops.

questions.question: What is the most common name for a loop variable?
questions.explanation: The most common loop variable name is i, which is short for index or iterator, though any valid identifier can be used.

questions.question: When does loop termination occur?

options.value: When the loop condition becomes false

questions.explanation: Loop termination occurs when the loop condition becomes false, causing execution to continue with the next statement after the loop.

questions.question: What does the loop condition determine?
questions.explanation: The loop condition determines whether the loop continues executing. If true, the loop body executes; if false, the loop terminates.
This loop counts down from 10 to 1 by decrementing i each iteration. When i reaches 0, the condition i > 0 becomes false and the loop stops.

questions.question: What must the loop update do for proper termination?

options.value: Move the loop variable toward the termination condition

questions.explanation: The loop update must move the loop variable toward the termination condition to ensure the loop eventually terminates naturally.
The initialization is int count = 1, which sets up the loop variable before the loop begins execution.

questions.question: Why are loops essential in programming?

options.value: They automate repetitive tasks that would be impractical to write manually

questions.explanation: Loops are essential because they automate repetitive tasks that would be impractical to write manually, making programs more powerful and efficient.
After the loop terminates (when countdown reaches 0), execution continues with the next statement, printing "Liftoff!".
The update is temperature += 2, which modifies the loop variable each iteration to make progress toward termination.

questions.question: When is the loop condition evaluated?
questions.explanation: The loop condition is evaluated before each iteration to determine if the loop body should execute or if the loop should terminate.
